On Sat, 5 May 2001, [iso-8859-1] Michael L=E9pine wrote:

> I am fairly new=
 to JUnit and am leading its integration at work. The one
> question I get =
a lot is, "How do we test the results of a database query?"
> The former me=
thod of testing the query, was to manually review the results.
> The one so=
lution we've come up with is to perform the query, save the
> results to a =
file, then assert that the results from the live query are
> equivalent to =
the stored results in the file. This gets a little more tricky
> when the r=
esults data contains time-sensitive fields (i.e. date fields).
> 
> Anyway,=
 I just wanted to know whether anyone had come up with a simpler
> and/or b=
etter solution.
 
What I do for this sort of thing (not databases, mind you=
) is to
use the output from toString() as the test.  If that isn't suitable=
,
I'll make a method that suits the test better.   This method can
replace =
things like time-sensitive fields with fixed values so that
tests don't bre=
ak.

My tests send up being simple assertEquals against two strings,
one co=
ming from a static constant, the other from the result object.

I wrote a l=
ittle tool in perl that reads an input file and writes a
java statement tha=
t reproduces the file as a string.  I've used this
to take captured results=
 and convert them to reference data for use in
Unit tests.
